facts.text: Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving surviving two widows Radhabai (senior widow) and Gangabai (junior widow) and a son Dattatraya.
Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath.
Gangabai survived both her son and grandson.
Factum of adoption upheld by trial court.
Gangabai alleged senior widow Radhabai gave consent to adoption.
Trial court held Radhabai did not give consent to adoption.

Plaintiff instituted suit on 15th March 1944 in forma pauperis claiming to be adopted son of Krishtarao entitled to possession of adoptive father's properties and declaration re compensation money for land acquired by Hubli Municipality.

Defendants are sons and grandsons of first cousin of Krishtarao; disputed adoption on ground Gangabai's power extinguished when Dattatraya died leaving widow Sundarabai and son Jagannath to continue family line.
Trial court (Civil Judge Senior Division Hubli, Special Suit No. 56/1944) dismissed suit on 30th July 1946 upholding defendants' contention.
High Court of Bombay in Appeal No. 274 of 1948 affirmed trial court on 2nd September 1949 holding Gangabai's power ended when son died leaving son and widow.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on 24th September 1951.

legal_issues.text: Whether a widow can exercise a power of adoption conferred on her or possessed by her at any time during her life irrespective of any devolution of property or changes in the family or other circumstances and even after a grandson has come on the scene but has subsequently died without leaving a widow or a son.

petitioner_arguments.text: Hindu Shastric Law itself sets no limit to the exercise of the widow's power of adoption once she has acquired that power or is possessed of it, and thus the power can be exercised by her during her lifetime when necessity arises for continuing the line of her husband.

Power suspended during son's lifetime revives on son dying sonless and unmarried; logically revives when son, widow, grandson and his widow all die out; adoption for spiritual reasons, devolution of property secondary.

respondent_arguments.text: Though Hindu Shastric Law sets no limit, judicially recognised that power is not unlimited and absolute; comes to an end when another heir has come on the scene and passed on duty of continuing the line.

court_reasoning.text: Reviews Privy Council decisions: Bhoobun Moyee v. Ram Kishore (1876/1865), Padma Coomari v. Court of Wards (1881), holds power incapable when son leaves widow as heir.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power ends upon vesting of estate in son's widow.

court_reasoning.text: Affirms Thayammal v. Venkatarama (1887), Tarachurn v. Suresh Chunder (1889); approves Bombay Full Bench Ramkrishna v. Shamrao (1902): power extinguished when son dies leaving son or widow competent to continue line.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principle: power once extinguished cannot revive.

court_reasoning.text: Amarendra Mansingh v. Sanatan (1933): reorients to spiritual aspect; interposition of grandson or son's widow ends power; mere birth of son or ceremonial competence does not; power revives only if son dies sonless unmarried before competence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty passed to grandson ends mother's power permanently.

court_reasoning.text: Rule applied in Madana Mohana v. Purushothama (1918), Vijaysingji v. Shivsangji (1935), Anant Bhikappa v. Shankar (1943); affirmed in Shrinivas Krishnarao (SC 1955 but prospective).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule part of Hindu Law for three quarters century based on justice, equity.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects revival on death of grandson citing true basis: duty assumed by son and passed to grandson ends power; distinguishes/rejects Bapuji v. Gangaram (Nagpur), Prem Jagat Kuer (Lucknow) as erroneous.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No revival after interposition competent to continue line.

holdings.text: Widow's power to adopt comes to an end by interposition of grandson or son's widow competent to continue line by adoption; once extinguished, cannot revive.

precedents_cited.relevance: Power incapable when son marries and leaves widow as heir.

precedents_cited.case_name: Padma Coomari v. Court of Wards
precedents_cited.relevance: Confirms power ends on vesting in son's widow.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thayammal and Kuttiswami Aiyan v. Venkatarama Aiyan

precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench: power extinguished on son leaving widow or son; cannot revive.
Approves Bombay principle; power ends when adopted son dies after competence.
Interposition of grandson or son's widow ends power; spiritual duty basis; revives only if son dies incompetent sonless.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anant Bhikappa Patil v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil
Shrinivas Krishnarao Kango v. Narayan Devji Kango

precedents_cited.relevance: Erroneous; wrongly interprets Amarendra; power does not revive on son's widow remarriage.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prem Jagat Kuer v. Harihar Bakhsh Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Follows erroneous Nagpur case under misapprehension.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed upholding High Court and trial court; Gangabai's adoption of Gurunath in 1943 invalid as her power to adopt extinguished in 1913 when Dattatraya died leaving son Jagannath and widow Sundarabai competent to continue line.

key_quotes.text: the true rule is this When a son dies before attaining full legal competence and does not leave either a widow or a son or an adopted son then the power of the mother which was in abeyance during his lifetime revives but the moment he hands over that torch to another, the mother can no longer take it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines precise limit on revival of widow's power.

key_quotes.text: It is too late in the day to say that there are no limitations of any kind on the widow's power to adopt excepting those that limit the power of her husband to adopt.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms judicially evolved rule as part of Hindu Law.

key_quotes.text: the substitution of a son of the deceased for spiritual reasons is the essence of the thing, and the consequent devolution of property a mere accessory to it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Amarendra; emphasizes spiritual basis over property.
